required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of iSTAR Medical's MINIject™ Implant for Lowering Intraocular Pressure (IOP) in Subjects With Primary Open-angle Glaucoma.
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Multicenter Masked Clinical Trial to Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of the MINIject CS627 Implant in Subjects With Open Angle Glaucoma

brief_summary.textblock: Evaluate the safety and effectiveness of iSTAR Medical's MINIject™ implant for lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) in subjects with primary open-angle glaucoma.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective, multicenter, masked clinical trial to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of iSTAR Medical's MINIject™ implant for lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) in subjects with primary open-angle glaucoma.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The MINIject™ SO627 is an integrated system for Minimally Invasive Glaucoma Surgery (MIGS) comprised of a glaucoma drainage implant, the MINIject™ SO627 and the SO Delivery System, designed to deliver the MINIject™ implant into the supraciliary space. The MINIject™ SO627 implant is manufactured from proprietary STAR® silicone material.
study_design_info.masking_description: Person(s) checking intraocular pressures are masked, except for day of surgery, throughout the duration of the trial.

primary_outcome.description: Proportion of subjects with ≥ 20% decrease (responders) from Baseline in unmedicated DIOP at Month 24.
Change from baseline in mean unmedicated diurnal IOP at Month 24.

intervention.description: The MINIject™ SO627 is an integrated system for Minimally Invasive Glaucoma Surgery (MIGS) comprised of a glaucoma drainage implant, the MINIject™ SO627 and the SO Delivery System, designed to deliver the MINIject™ implant into the supraciliary space.

criteria.textblock:
Key Inclusion Criteria:
- Males and females, 46 years of age or older
- A diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma, who are candidates for medical therapy, laser treatment, or glaucoma-filtering surgery
- Pseudophakic with prior uncomplicated cataract surgery
Key Exclusion Criteria:
- Angle closure, congenital, or secondary glaucoma
- Diagnosed degenerative visual disorders
- Clinically significant intraocular inflammation or infection
